review_title: Salem State College- The Best Place to Work in the field of Higher Education

Love the people/ love the students/Love the college.

job_title: Professor of Communications in Salem, MA
pros: The university is a century and a half old fixture on the N. Shore of Mass. It boasts an extremely caring, devoted and student-centered faculty, many of whom are actively researching and publishing in journals and writing scholarly books. (Me included.) In the past decade, the university has broken ground on several new dorms, a state of the art library, a gorgeous student athletic center and has plans for a new science center. The graduates of the university include the mayor of Salem and numerous successful professionals. Student are succeeding. Getting internships and jobs.  Students making the choice to attend the university are not looking at $60K annually and crushing debt. The university is still a bargain. Commuters may attend for around $10 K. Double that to be residential. A third of our new enrollees are students of color. The faculty is typically highly supportive face-to-face with their students. The presidential leadership has been highly effective.
cons: Reputation continues to suffer, in large part due to two major factors: One,  the withdrawal of resource support from a legislature whose members have tended to graduate from private, elite colleges. This region has the highest concentration of elite private higher Ed in the nation-- Harvard. MIT. Tufts. Wellesley.Smith. BU. Boston College and many others.

review_title: A place where faculty make a real difference
pros: As full-time faculty, we really make a difference in our students' lives. Also many opportunities to be involved in shared governance, to shape the curriculum, and to grow into leadership roles. A lot of flexibility re: what type of scholarship we pursue. Overall a good place to be.
cons: Revolving-door administration. Huge turnover of administrators at dean and VP level in past decade has meant a vacuum of leadership. Experience of faculty varies greatly from department to department (some are very supportive, others not) and from administration to administration. Terrible maternity leave policies (10 days, plus sick time and unpaid FMLA) a serious concern for junior faculty looking to start families.

review_title: Great Organization for Entry Level, Hard to Get Recognition or Move Up the Ladder
pros: There are numerous opportunities to improve outcomes for students and to get hands on experience
cons: There is little recognition for assisting with strategic goals and it is unclear how to move up in the organization. Also, there seems to be an issue sharing power with associate and assistant directors. There's a disconnect between the different levels of management, which results in the efforts and achievements of those at lower levels being ignored or underappreciated. The organization of the university also needs to be reconfigured to provide a better work-life balance for departments that end up duplicating efforts of other departments through the current structure.

review_title: A lively network fulfilled in professional career building
pros: Faculty and student staff are willing to resolve problems effectively without detouring truth.  Everything around the campus is always up to date and up to code.  Salem State is one of the friendliest atmospheres I have ever experienced in my undergraduate career.
cons: At times, I felt I had to do the work of three others when data was getting lost or input was not looked over and entered correctly.  There are some loop holes in administration when students are asked to go out of their way to do extra footwork that staff can easily do electronically.  I have watched students walk away stressed because they cannot start their class schedules on time.
